body:
Interesting suggestion!

Though I should point out that this is related to annotation and online annotators.
E.g., CUSUM is a classical on-line anomaly detector, Triple-Barriers is classical (backwards) annotator.

You are making a specific choice here, namely to implement these as transformers.
That's not an entirely off-track choice, but could you be more specific about how this would interact with how we implement or formalise annotator scitypes? Perhaps it's worth making more explicit the information how the transformed series "annotates" an original variable or series?

issue.title: Added STEP for ForecastingPipeline
issue.body:
Added STEP for ForecastingPipeline
___
Martin Walter <martin_friedrich.walter@daimler.com>, Mercedes-Benz AG on behalf of Daimler TSS GmbH.
https://github.com/Daimler/daimler-foss/blob/master/LEGAL_IMPRINT.md

body: @fkiraly @ViktorKaz I'm happy to integrate this functionality, but we need to break it down into smaller work packages/PRs.

> ```python
> pipeline = OnlineUnsupervisedPipeline(
>     [
>         ('feature_extraction', DollarBars(price_col ='Price', volume_col ='Volume'), input_values={'X':'original_series'} ), # input_values={'X':'original_series'} can be omitted
>         ('changepoint_detection',CUSUM(), input_values={'X':'feature_extraction'}),
>         ('labeling', TripleBarrier(price_col='closing_price'), input_values={ 'change_points':'changepoint_detection', 'prices':'feature_extraction'}), 
>         ('build_dataset', DatasetBuilder(lookback=20), input_values={ 'untransformed_series':'original_series','changepoint_detection':'changepoint_detection'}), 
>         ('estimator',SVC(), input_values={'X':'build_dataset','y':'labelling'})
>     ]
> )
> pipeline.fit(X)
> ```

For example, the above code seems to combine annotation and reduction from (directional) forecasting to tabular classification.  We need to separately define APIs for annotation and directional forecasting including the reduction to classification.
Do you want to start by integrating the [pipeline object](https://github.com/ViktorKaz/sktime/blob/pipeline/sktime/pipeline/pipeline.py)? I can create a PR just for it.

Yes, agreed with @mloning - this touches estimators of multiple scientific types (directional forecasters, change point detectors), for which we may like to introduce support and template separately. Would it be a good idea to start with directional forecasters, before adding a pipeline for directional forecasters?

> Do you want to start by integrating the [pipeline object](https://github.com/ViktorKaz/sktime/blob/pipeline/sktime/pipeline/pipeline.py)? I can create a PR just for it.

The pipeline seems to be the most complex object, combining multiple APIs (reduction and directional forecasting). So I would start with simple components, either directional forecasters or annotators. 

Since there is some ongoing work on annotation (#798), directional forecasting seems like a good starting point. 

I suggest to implement the following first: 
* an abstract base class: `BaseDirectionalForecaster` which defines the interface (should be the same as `BaseForecaster` except that predict returns a series of categorical values if I understand this correctly)
* a concrete algorithm (if you want to start with reduction to classification, see `make_reduction(...)` in `sktime/forecasting/compose/_reduce.py`)
* a loss function to evaluate categorical forecasts (see #718)
* a unit testing framework, see e.g. `sktime/forecasting/tests/test_all_forecasters.py`
* a short example notebook for documentation

issue.title: Network Pipeline

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
### Reference Issues/PRs
Aimed at addressing [Forecasting Pipelining enhancement proposal.](https://github.com/sktime/enhancement-proposals/blob/main/steps/01_forecasting_api/forecasting-with-exogenous-variables.md#forecasting-pipelining)

This is also with reference to Issue #763 and Issue #844.

### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.

This is a draft PR proposing a design for a more flexible "network" pipeline. The general idea of this network pipeline is that the steps comprising the pipeline are not chained, i.e. the output of a step is not necessarily the input for the next step. Instead, the output of any step can serve as input to any other step in the pipeline. 

The steps of the pipeline are specified as tuple following the convention below:
```python
('step_name', Algorithm, arguments)
```
`step_name` is a string with the name of the step
`Algorithm` can be `sktime.transformations.base.BaseTransformer` or `sktime.base.BaseEstimator`.
`arguments` is a dictionary that is substituted in the `fit`, `fit_transform` or `predict` method of the step.

The `arguments` dictionary can use the following key words: `original_X` and `original_y` which refer to the `X` and `y` arguments of  `NetworkPipeline.fit` and `NetworkPipeline.predcit` methods.

The `arguments` dictionary can refer to the output of any step of the pipeline by the name of the step.

The `arguments` dictionary can specify different arguments for `NetworkPipeline.fit` or `NetworkPipeline.predict`

```python
# Forecasting example. Note convention for specifying different arguments 
# depending on whether NetworkPipeline.fit or  NetworkPipeline.predict is called.

pipe = NetworkPipeline(
    steps=[
        ("imputer", Imputer(method="drift"), {"fit": {"Z": "original_y"}, "predict": None}),
        ("forecaster", NaiveForecaster(strategy="last", sp=12), {"fit": {"y": "imputer"}, "predict": {"fh": "original_y"}})
    ]
)

# Classification example
pipe = NetworkPipeline(
        steps=[
            ("tabularizer", Tabularizer(), {"X": "original_X"}),
            ( "classifier", DummyClassifier(strategy="prior"), {
                         fit": {"X": "tabularizer", "y": "original_y"},
                         "predict": {"X": "tabularizer"} })
        ]
    )
```

### Questions

- Is proposed interface intuitive?
- Should the steps be executed sequentially or in any order defined by the user? This would be achieved if the `arguments` dictionary can refer to future steps. This feature is not currently supported in my design.

### TODO
- [ ] Improve examples by adding more than two steps.
- [ ] Write checks and tests.

issue.title: [DOC]The problem with the transition from scikit to sktime, especially for data preparation.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
#### Describe the issue linked to the documentation

<!--
Tell us about the confusion introduced in the documentation.
-->
Hey, first of all , i'd like to thank you guys for the contribution made to time series analyze. If you want to make sktime more popular, the documentation's readability&understand-ability is so important, especially the topic like data preparation. Since most of us are  familiar with the pandas and scikit, the transition is quit important for us. 
 
I have a multi-variate classification task.
My dataframe like below:
![panel](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41810121/180977283-adca0d25-4e7a-4b6b-8aa9-5b34c34369eb.JPG)
Due to some reason,some symbol lost some days records, like  #1 symblol has 1000 dates rows while #2 symblol only has 500 dates rows. I want use last 11 lags to classify current label's value. For example, for the first row, I will take the OHLC from the date 2014-10-30 to  2014-10-19, to predict the date of 2014-10-30's label. 
First of all, I convert the pandas(multi-index) to sktime's mtype(pd-multiindex)
data=pd.read_csv('etf_labels.csv',encoding='utf-8',parse_dates=[1])
data.sort_values(by=['symbol','date'], ascending=[True,True],inplace=True)
data.set_index(['symbol','date'],drop=True,inplace=True)
y_train, y_test, X_train, X_test = temporal_train_test_split(y, X, test_size=30)
# fit
hc2.fit(X_train, y_train)

ValueError: y must be a np.array or a pd.Series, but found type: <class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>

if change y_train to y_train.values
hc2.fit(X_train, y_train.values)
then
ValueError: Mismatch in number of cases. Number in X = 1 nos in y = 2424

finally, i have read more than 2 days for the section of the data preparation, but still confused.
#### Suggest a potential alternative/fix

<!--
To enhance the document's readability and understand-ability, the detailed and complete example is preferable. 
-->
